benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/customFields/search - Search custom fields by type, name and optional value

covered: Valid requests: Multiple scenarios (TC01–TC07, TC37) validate successful searches for combinations of objectType, fieldName, and fieldValue and assert 200 responses with JSON array payloads.
Empty responses / state variations: TC11 (no matches), TC28 (empty DB), and TC29 (partially populated DB) verify handling of no-data and partial-data states.
Pagination basics and edges: TC07 (limit & offset), TC21 (very large limit), and TC22 (offset beyond data size) cover primary pagination functionality and boundary behavior.
Query parameters: TC02–TC06, TC12, TC13–TC16, and TC37 exercise valid, invalid, extra, and partial parameter combinations.
Audit handling and integration: TC08–TC10 (FULL/MINIMAL/NONE) plus TC32–TC33 verify audit payloads and behavior when the audit service is degraded or inconsistent.
Authorization: TC17 validates missing/invalid authentication (401) behavior.
Error handling & validation: TC13–TC16, TC19, TC20, and TC35 cover invalid input, SQLi/XSS attempts, and descriptive error messages.
Security: Explicit tests for SQL injection (TC19) and XSS (TC20) attacks are present.
Performance & load: TC24, TC30, and TC31 include performance/response-time expectations under normal, heavy, and peak loads.
Concurrency/resilience: TC23 covers concurrent request correctness; TC36 covers retry/recovery from transient network failures.
Dependent service availability: TC18 covers audit-service unavailability with expected 503; TC33 covers slow/degraded audit service behavior.
Regression & backward compatibility: TC25–TC27 cover previously fixed bugs and legacy-client behavior.
Documentation & accessibility: TC34 ensures the API docs describe params, responses, and errors.
Response schema: At least one scenario (TC01) explicitly requires objects to conform to the CustomField schema and many scenarios assert JSON array responses (partial schema coverage).
gaps: Rate limiting / throttling: No explicit tests that exercise rate limiting or throttling behavior (e.g., generating 429 responses and verifying Retry-After headers).
Caching behavior and headers: No scenarios check ETag/If-None-Match, Cache-Control, Last-Modified, or 304 responses for conditional GETs.

Default pagination semantics & limit boundary: No explicit test asserting the documented default limit (default=100) when limit is omitted; TC01's "fetch all" wording is ambiguous relative to the default limit. There are also no tests for upper-limit enforcement (what happens if client requests limit greater than allowed) or for limit boundary values immediately above/below allowed bounds.
Content-Type & response headers: No explicit assertions that responses include correct Content-Type (application/json) or other expected headers.
Consistent schema validation: Schema conformance is asserted in a few scenarios only; the suite lacks uniform schema validation across all success responses and pagination pages.
Authorization nuance: No tests for authorized-but-forbidden cases (403) or role-based access control scenarios if applicable.

Pagination ordering / stable paging: No tests assert a deterministic sort order for results or validate that pagination across pages is stable and consistent (e.g., no missing/duplicate items across pages).
Precise error-code contract: Many negative tests accept 400 or 422 interchangeably; there are no tests that assert the exact canonical error code per the API contract for each invalid input case.
recommendations: Add explicit rate-limiting tests that fire many requests in a short window to assert 429 responses and the presence/semantics of Retry-After header and backoff behavior.
Add caching tests: assert Cache-Control and ETag headers on responses; test conditional GETs with If-None-Match to verify 304 behavior and reduced payloads.

Clarify and test default pagination: add a scenario that explicitly verifies default limit=100 when no limit param is provided and adjust TC01 (or split it) so expectations match the API spec (i.e., "up to 100" vs "all").
Add boundary tests for limit (e.g., negative, zero, very large >max) to assert exact error codes or truncation behavior and an explicit test for the system's maximum allowed limit.
Add explicit header checks (Content-Type: application/json and any required audit/trace headers) in success and error scenarios.
Enforce schema validation across all success scenarios (including paged responses) using the canonical CustomField JSON schema; fail tests if extra/missing fields occur.
Add tests for authorization nuances: authorized-but-forbidden (403) and role/permission variations if the API supports RBAC.
Add stable-pagination / ordering tests to ensure results are returned in a deterministic order and to validate no duplicates or missing items across sequential pages.
Tighten negative test expectations: choose and assert the exact API error code (400 vs 422) per invalid-input scenario according to the API contract, rather than allowing either.
Consider adding stress tests that combine rate limiting + authentication + large pagination to see behavior under compound load and to validate graceful degradation.
